title: the best way to fix our broken elitist political system is to get more working class kids into university
story: I suspect not, and that won’t just be because few people have really caught who Damian Hinds is.The Education Secretary made some comments about higher education which were all but buried by the deluge of coverage of his own party tearing itself up over Europe.While Conservative MPs were discussing whether they were now stuck with Theresa May for ever after the attempt to boot her out of office failed, Hinds was poring over statistics from universities admissions body UCAS, which showed that a record proportion of English and Scottish -year-olds were accepted into university in .The minister wasn’t very happy though, because his department’s own data shows that teenagers from white working-class backgrounds are the least likely to go to universities — and even less likely to end up in a top institution.“There is no reason why a white working-class child growing up in Sunderland or Somerset should be less likely to go to university than any other child growing up in this country,” he said, telling universities that they need to “look at your own admissions policies and work out what you can do to ensure that your university is open to everyone who has the potential, no matter their background or where they are from”.Universities can’t just expect students to come to them. They need to do far more when it comes to outreach, actually visiting isolated and deprived areas and talking to children years before they start thinking about university.Otherwise, a child growing up in a community where very few people have a degree will believe university just isn’t for them.The top universities all have their own outreach policies, and don’t work together to reach particularly under-represented parts of the country, which means entire towns can often end up being ignored.The political world doesn’t help, either. A young, white, working-class boy might not think he fits into the current Parliament, and so a vicious cycle of the same sort of people from the same sort of backgrounds going into politics continues. We know all the figures about the percentage of MPs who went to private schools , or that  prime ministers were schooled at Eton.But what we are less likely to realise is that there are entire towns in this country that have never, ever had an MP who was born and schooled locally.Or that the cost of getting into politics means thatyou are from a working-class background, your only hope of becoming an MP is landing a well-paid job first. And that tends to be easieryou’ve been to university.MPs tend to recruit their researchers straight from university. Researchers go on to become special advisers or take other political jobs before becoming MPs, so the political gene pool is articially shallow from the beginning.It’s handy to have MPs who hail from all kinds of backgrounds, but especially useful to have people who grew up in tough circumstances.When governments make mistakes, it is usually the most vulnerable people who suffer first. A Parliament of old Etonians can’t always instinctively realise when a policy is going to cause trouble.I don’t need to tell you that the current Parliament isn’t working very well.From those at the top of government who have failed to take big decisions on Brexit, to the backbenchers who have been busy plotting away, a lot of people in Westminster seem to be lacking a sense of perspective.This week the drama has all been about Brexit, but the infighting means that serious policy problems on social care, domestic abuse and, yes, education are largely ignored.If we made it easier for any bright kid from any background to get to university, perhaps we would have more competition for Parliamentary seats — and end up with better politicians.SoDamian Hinds got his way with universities, he’d be putting the future mediocre politicians out of a job.There might even be entire weeks in politics when you’d have a chance of noticing comments made by the Education Secretary, rather than being distracted by the self-indulgent way in which politicians of all persuasions have ended up conducting themselves.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mps pressure theresa may dog eating follow us ban
story: Congress passed legislation yesterday to outlaw the human consumption of dog and cat meat across America.The move was drawn up to send a powerful moral message to Far East countries to also end the sick practice, where it is popular.In August, Downing Street pledged to look closely at the US plan but the Government has so far failed to take any action.Members of Parliament from across the political ide last night demanded the UK follows suit.Labour’s shadow animal welfare minister David Drew said: “This is an incredibly important commitment from the US.“The UK government needs to stand up for man’s best friend and ensure that we are upholding our reputation as leaders in animal welfare. This is the time for the UK to lead by example.Tory MP Bill Wiggin threatened to enforce a ban himself by hijacking government laws or tabling his own.Mr Wiggin said: “Representing a nation of dog lovers, the UK Government could act now to protect our canine companions and join the US in bringing in a ban.“I will be looking for opportunities in  to put down legislation which will seek to bring in a ban on eating dogs to strengthen global condemnation of this practice”.The American ban, in an amendment to the US Farm Bill, is punishable by a fine of up to US,.Eating dog is already banned in Germany, Austria, Taiwan, South Australia and Hong Kong.An estimated  million dogs a year are slaughtered to be eaten, across China, the Philippines, Indonesia, Thailand, Laos, Vietnam and Cambodia.Their meat it is considered both a delicacy and a health tonic.As The Sun revealed in August, The World Dog Alliance launched a campaign in the UK for a full ban on any activity relating to the eating of dogs.Foreign Office minister Sir Alan Duncan has also spoken out to back a total ban, dubbing it a “disgusting habit”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what does nebulous mean junker theresa may
story: But what does nebulous mean  And why did the European Commission boss use the word to describe the Prime Minister The word nebulous is an adjective and can either mean something is hazy or in the form of a cloud, or something is vague or ill-defined.Its likely Juncker was using the latter definition to describe May, insinuating she may have been unspecic in what she was saying.Theresa May has been known for dodging questions about Brexit, so its hardly surprising shes been called out for being vague.The pair were filmed having a standoff at the EU summit and an expert lipreader has now determined what the pair were saying.May is seen to say You called me nebulous. Yes you did! to Juncker, who had one hand on Mays arm.Body language experts have said May successfully disrupted Junckers dominating persona and put him on the back foot.It is reported that Juncker was referring specically to Mays Brexit deal.The PM insisted she was crystal clear in talks with EU leaders about the need to fix the hated backstop - and warned Britain will leave with No DealBrussels doesnt give in.At a press conference this afternoon, the PM said: I was crystal clear about the assurances which are needed on the backstop having heard the views of MPs in the House of Commons.I reiterated that it is in the interests of the EU as well as the UK to get this over the line. A disorderly Brexit would be good for no one.Asked about her clash with Mr Juncker, Mrs May said: I had a robust discussion with Jean-Claude Juncker - I think thats the sort of discussion youre able to have when you have a working relationship and you work well together.When he used that phrase hed been talking about the general level of debate.

title: eu pm dignified change course now
story: Why should the Prime Minister of our great country suffer further abuse at the clammy hands of the shambling, brandy-soaked buffoon Jean-Claude Juncker Or playground taunts from the pipsqueak president of little Lithuania over our perceived Brexit indecision  This is the thanks we get for sending British troops to risk their lives defending the Baltic states from Russian aggression.This latest summit charade was not, in fact, wrecked by Mrs May’s vagueness. As other leaders said, she was very ­specic about the legally binding text she needed to convince the DUP and her backbenchers to approve the deal.The two-day meeting was actually scuppered by an agreement suddenly being trashed by Ireland and France.Do they have any inkling how much goodwill between our nations they have destroyed with their parlour games over the past ½ years  How many once pro-EU Brits they convert into Leavers with every new salvo Do they not grasp how mistrustful, obstructive and even hostile we would become as an EU member , God forbid, Remain won a second referendum Senior Cabinet ministers including Sajid Javid and Jeremy Hunt are rightly imploring Mrs May to focus every effort on No Deal preparations. A “managed No Deal” to soften the impact after March  looks a decent idea to us.The Sun always wanted a deal. It’s not going to happen. The EU has other ideas.And a second referendum, or “Norway Plus”, both amount to craven surrenders to this bloated organisation which ­apparently ­relishes belittling Britain. We must get out.TONY Blair is a delusional egomaniac who has damaged Britain more than any politician we can recall.It was his negligence and naivety over dodgy intelligence that condemned  of our troops and countless Iraqis to their deaths during the  invasion.It was his decision to unleash a vast, uncontrolled influx of migrants on a country ill-equipped for it . . . all, as his adviser later admitted, to “rub the Right’s nose in ersity”.It was his lust for wealth after leaving office that saw him torch what was left of his reputation and line his pockets with dictators’ millions.Now Blair is hell-bent on setting a match to our democracy itself as he heads the campaign to reverse the biggest mandate in its history, sabotaging our Brexit negotiating position in the process.And so the trail of destruction he has left for  years goes on. The common thread being his unassailable conviction, despite every single catastrophic mistake, that Tony always knows best.Many of us stopped listening long ago. Time the rest woke up. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: shopkeeper rude christmas customer revenge
story: Sarah Belanger Demaneuf told her friends on Facebook how she got her own back on a cheapskate shopper who tried to haggle down the price of some festive decorations that were already heavily reduced.Sarah was working in a shop during the Christmas sales when a smartly dressed by “terrible” woman came in.The shop was selling off some Christmas decorations which were reduced by  percent and selling for just  cents each .But this seemed to be too high a price for the customer, who tried to haggle the price down to  cents.Sarah was having none of it and refused to drop the price.She wrote: “As we werent at a yard sale I said no. And she started arguing with me, becoming increasingly rude and belligerent.”Sarah added: After not bullying me into caving she said, Fine! My friend works at the other store in Huntsville and she told me that all the ornaments will be  percent off tomorrow, so Ill just come back in the morning. I cant guarantee theyll still be here, I said.And the jerk said, There are  in the store. No one is going to buy all . Ill get what I want, prepare to feel stupid tomorrow.To get her own back Sarah then bought up the entire stock herself and bought up all the other ones the nearby store had – as well as from two other shops in the area.Sarah said: “It was the most vengeful  I ever spent.”And the vengeful tale of events, which happened  years ago, didn’t end there.Sarah was behind the counter the following day when the rude customer ed, hoping to get those bargains.Sarah said: I had the pleasure of telling her that ALL of the star ornaments in North Alabama had been sold to one customer.“The look on her face was worth every penny spent.”Sarah eventually gave away all the ornaments she had bought to friends and family but kept one for herself – and said she smiled every year when she hangs it up on her tree.

title: brexit cabinet split second referendum no deal
story: Meanwhile, a Brexit-backing camp are urging Mrs Mays to prepare for a No Deal with the EU as the March  orce deadline moves closer.Chancellor Philip Hammond, Amber Rudd, David Gauke, Greg Clark and the PM’s unofficial deputy David Lidington have not committed to another referendum and could still embrace an alternative deal.However, The Sun can reveal that a group of Brexit-backers within the cabinet are urging a beleaguered Mrs May to prepare for a No Deal orce with the EU,Those urging the PM to prepare for a No Deal scenario include Home Secretary Sajid Javid, Liz Truss, Andrea Leadsom and Penny Mordaunt.The Remianer camp in the split cabinet want Mrs May to reschedule the parliamentary vote on her isive deal – possibly in the week starting January , reports The Times.They believe this would allow MPs time to vote on alternative options with the March  orce deadline looming.The group then believe thatmembers of parliament fail to reach a consensus then ministers should consider ignoring the UK’s historic Brexit vote and push for a second referendum.One cabinet minister said: “There should be a vote on all of the options.WHAT is a “managed No Deal” Britain would leave without a new free trade deal with the EU. But ministers would strike side deals with Brussels or EU nations in areas such as aviation, borders and financial services to avoid chaos.WHAT are the benefits Supporters claim it allows a “smooth” departure while letting Britain strike trade deals with the world. In theory we would only pay a fraction of the £billion orce bill.WHAT are the problems It still fails to solve the Irish border problem. Britain and Northern Ireland would sit outside the single market and customs union, meaning checks on goods to and from the Republic.WHO is pushing the idea Brexit-backing Tories such as Andrea Leadsom and Jacob Rees-Mogg, and this week Brexit-backing businessmen.WOULD the EU agree Brexiteers argue the PM has never got tough with the EU andit was Britain “crashing out” or a managed No Deal, Brussels would be desperate to agree.WOULD the PM agree She has repeatedly said it is her deal or nothing. Senior sources claim she is “terried” of a No Deal in any form.“I’d expect them all to be voted down. Then once you’ve taken out all the options, and the lack of support for no deal, the House of Commons is deadlocked.“Another vote is another means of resolving the deadlock.”The No Deal camp want the Prime Minister to agree to ert resources from the budget and signicantly “ramp up” preparations.This would include more money on IT systems, customs and stockpiling.One Cabinet Minister told The Sun: “It has to become our core planning assumption otherwise nothing is going to happen.“We have to show we’re serious – and we have to prepare.”On Wednesday, Ms Mordaunt, the International Development Secretary, urged the PM to put “crack on” with No Deal planning after surviving her no confidence vote.Yesterday, a raging Mrs May let rip at Jean-Claude Juncker — after he infuriated Britain by grabbing her and calling her plans “nebulous”.The Prime Minister confronted the EU Commission President after he tore into the UK over its Brexit negotiating strategy at a crunch summit in Brussels.Arriving for fresh talks the PM stunned onlookers by saying to Mr Juncker: “What did you call me  You called me nebulous, yes you did.”Lip-readers claimed he replied: “What  No I didn’t, no I didn’t.”Within hours he was forced into a grovelling retreat after being accused of deepening the ide with Britain.Challenged at a press conference he admitted the confrontation and joked that the pair “weren’t dancing”.He insisted he was referring to Britain’s vague negotiating stance and that he had the greatest respect for the PM.Yet in bizarre comments he then boasted: “In the course of the morning after having checked what I said yesterday night, she was kissing me.”

title: harry redknapp gives verdict theresa
story: NewsHarry Redknapp gives verdict on Theresa May getting up every day, getting slaughteredBBC presenter Rachel Burden interviewed the Im a Celebrity winner for his take on the Prime Ministers ongoing political woesShareCommentsByBethany Papworth:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video harry-redknapps-verdict-theresa-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEveryone has an opinion on our beleaguered Prime Minister right now. title: 11 christmas traditions every british
story: Advertorial Christmas traditions every British family follows... and why theyre all basically barmyIts the most wonderful time of the year...but its also the maddestShareCommentsByGary Bainbridge:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC Advertorial"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPractically every bit of the Great British Christmas is potty when you think about it. From putting foliage in our living rooms to pretending that sausages wrapped in bacon are a vegetable, we dont half have some strange traditions at this time of year. So to celebrate the hilariously dysal Dave family at Christmas, weve come up with the  weirdest of them all! Thats one for every day of Christmas, apart from the tenth, because who really has room for  lords, leaping or otherwise.  And dont forget, Christmas on Dave continues tonight at :pm with Alan Davies: Xmas Untitled.  Sending cards to people we live with  There are some very good reasons for sending Christmas cards to people you are not going to see at Christmas. For instance, whatyour Auntie Flo thinks that, unaccountably, you dont want her to have a Merry Christmas and or Happy New Year  You can put her mind at rest with regard to whether you wish her Seasons Greetings with a simple trip to the post box. But do we really need to give Christmas cards to people who use the same bar of soap as you  Do we really need to risk a paper cut on the tongue to wish close family members a cool Yule, when you could just shout it into their faces  Yes, apparently we do.  Putting foliage in your living room  - “What are you doing, Brian ” - “Ive just been out to cut down a tree.” - “What, for firewood ” - “No, I am going to bring it indoors.” - “What, an entire living tree ” - “Of course not!” - “Good!” - “Its dead now. Anyway, Im going to stand it up in a bucket and then cover its slowly drying and decaying branches with glittering scarves, shiny balls, and colourful lights.” - “But thats insane.” - “Yes, but its December.” - “Fair enough, carry on.”  Going to the work do  Ah, the office Christmas party! What are we thinking  Whose idea was it to say, “I know, lets gather together people we have to pay to spend time together normally, with all their resentments about the tea round, and put them in a big room with loud music and freely flowing alcohol. What could possibly go wrong ” Indeed, what could possibly go wrong with getting roaring drunk on a night out with your boss   Blackmailing children into behaving  We spend most of the year telling children to beware of strangers. And then, from the middle of November, we tell them that,they be good, a man with a big beard and a sack will break into their home in the dead of night and leave some presents behind. And all the children hear is “be good” and “presents”. And now we have introduced the element of a -hour snitch, the elf on a shelf, to keep our kids honest, in case they were a bit suspicious of Father Christmass ability to find out whos been naughty or nice. Of course, the clever kids keep it to themselves that theyve realised that they get Christmas presents from everybody they know except their parents. Hmm...  Getting an early start Alcohol plays a prominent part in the typical family Christmas. Indeed, it might even be essential, depending on which relatives are visiting. But the important thing is to pace yourself. Dont peak too soon. It would be mad, say, to start at breakfast time. Unless youre putting champagne in your orange juice. Straight off the bat, thats one of your five-a-day. Orange juice and grape juice  That might actually be two of your five-a-day. Its practically a health drink… right   Pretending that satsumas are a treat  Its , for heavens sake. Stop treating easily obtainable citrus fruit as an exotic jewel from the mystic east. Its a Christmas stocking, not your childrens lunch box.  Doing Christmas dinner “with a twist”  OK, OK. Christmas dinner is predictable. But guess what  Its supposed to be. You dont complain there isnt a surprising “-past Belgium” between five-past two and ten-past two on the clock, so dont grumble about the fact its turkey again. You remember what happened when you had goose that year  Exactly. Anyway,youre making Christmas dinner, you are allowed to have only one item “with a twist” or theres going to be mutiny. And, realistically, that means you get to do something fiddly with sprouts. In fact, its chestnuts. Its always chestnuts.  Pretending that sausages wrapped in bacon are a vegetable  Christmas is no time for a vegetarian. The centrepiece of the festive dinner is some meat stuffed with more meat. And then, to garnish this, we add some cylinders of meat wrapped in more meat. And somehow we can eat as many of these cylinders as we like, because its basically just like eating extra carrots or sprouts. Christmas dinner is the the only dinner where you can feel relatively virtuous by eating a roast potato.  Sabotaging pudding  Imagine youre eating a nice dessert, in a restaurant, say. Perhaps a lovely sticky toffee pudding. And youre tucking in happily. And then you bite down on a hard piece of metal. Would you call over the waiter and ask him to pass on your compliments to the chef  Or would you leave a very tart review on TripAdvisor  But at Christmas finding an actual coin in your pudding is considered lucky, rather than actionable. It isnt even an accident. Somebody, in fact, a supposed loved one, has intentionally put shrapnel in your dessert. All you can hope is that one of the crackers has instructions on the Heimlich manoeuvre inside.  Playing board games  It always seems like a good idea at the time. What could be nicer than getting the family around the table to play a game after the Christmas dinner has been cleared away  The family, they say, that plays together stays together. The problem is that the family that plays together, cant decide which game theyre going to play. Nor can they agree on the rules, even though theyre very clearly printed on the box. But there is only one game to which everybody knows the rules, and that is snakes and ladders, and it is impossible to cheat in snakes and ladders on behalf of your six-year-old child. Andyour overtired six-year-old child, who has been up since ., cant win, nobody wins.  Explaining whats going on in Doctor Who to Nana

title: boy 6 who lost mum
story: NewsBoy, , who lost mum and brother in crash gets touching Christmas surpriseBrave Kyle Rhodes suffered agonising injuries including a broken leg, internal injuries, a large cut to his neck and damage to his lungs and spleenShareCommentsByLouise Elliott:,  DEC NewsKyle Rhodes has won the Santa Sleepover at Alton Towers "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA boy who lost his mum and little brother in an horric car crash is getting a special Christmas treat. Brave Kyle Rhodes, six, was also seriously injured in the crash and suffered agonising injuries including a broken leg, internal injuries, a large cut to his neck and damage to his lungs and spleen. The youngster, who now lives with his paternal grandparents, has sadly said he isnt looking forward to Christmas this year, according to his grandma Pat. But friends of the family are hoping he will have something to look forward to after he won a Christmas party with a Santa Sleepover at Alton Towers this weekend. Kyles mum Rebecca Smith,  and five-year old brother Corey Rhodes ere rushed to hospital following the accident in Draycott in August of this year, The Stoke Sentinel reports.  The vile Christmas con that cost Lillian every one of her planned presents But Corey was pronounced dead a short time later and Rebecca died the following day. Kyle was taken by air ambulance to Sheffields Childrens Hospital, where he underwent surgery and had his leg pinned. He is now living with his dad Jamess parents Pat and Jeff Rhodes. Pat, aged , of Well Street, Cheadle, said: We have had a very, very dficult year - especially Kyle. He saw his little brother die. He was extremely close to Corey and misses him so much - he keeps clinging to his grandad, but doesnt talk about the accident. He has blanked it out. Following the accident, Jeff, aged , who works at JCB, took bereavement leave to help look after Kyle with his we who is retired.  Pat said: We are getting used to doing the school run and dealing with paying for school dinners etc, but its all changed since our two sons were at school. Jeff is due to go back to work soon. Because Kyle is so close to his grandad its going to be very dficult, but well get through it. Kyle, a former pupil of Clarice Clf School in Fenton, now attends St Giles Catholic Primary School in Cheadle, where he has been receiving counselling. Pat said: He has started to make friends at school. Ive seen him playing with dferent children and he does his homework every night, but hes very, very quiet. We are trying to make Christmas extra special for him this year and have put a tree and decorations up but he has ignored them. I overheard a woman ask himhe was looking forward to Christmas the other day - he replied no.  To be nominated to win the Santa Sleepover was very, very nice and so kind. Margaret Chandler, who nominated Kyle and his grandparents, said: I saw the Alton Towers competition in The Stoke Sentinel and Kyle came to mind straightaway. After everything he has gone through, I see that little lad go into school every morning with a big smile on his face. Hes had a bad year and its just heart-breaking, but I just thought a little bit of magic will help make things easier for him and give him something to look forward to.The prize includes: Bed and breakfast in the Splash Landings Hotel A festive evening meal Tickets to the Alton Towers Alice in Wonderland pantomime A day ticket to the theme park A one-day entry to the waterpark A game of nine-hole extraordinary golf Evening entertainment including meet and greets and shows A special farewell from Santa Sentinel Editor Martin Tideswell said: We were absolutely overwhelmed with nominations for this brilliant competition prize donated by our friends at Alton Towers. In truth, every nominee was worthy and it was wonderful to see so many people make the time to put others forward for a special treat. Kyle has clearly had a terrible year. We hope this weekend he and his grandparents can make some lovely memories and know that our readers will join us in wishing him a magical time. Divisional Director at Alton Towers Resort, Ian Crabbe, said: “Our hearts go out to Kyle and his family who really do deserve a special treat this Christmas. At Alton Towers Resort, we are all dedicated to making sure our guests have a wonderful time with us, and go home with magical memories. So we’ll be pulling out all the stops to make sure that Kyle and his grandparents have a truly unforgettable ‘Santa Sleepover’.”

title: hidden journals dying dad reveal
story: NewsHidden journals of dying dad reveal horric final days after doctor misdiagnosed tumourAdrian Watts revealed he attempted suicide in journals which he hid in prison furniture over fears his death would be covered-upShareCommentsByMichael Yong:,  DEC Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video video-secret-journals-dying-bristol-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dying father revealed the horric pain he went through in his final days after medics misdiagnosed his stomach tumour. Adrian Watts spent months detailing his treatment at Bristol Prison before stashing his diaries in furniture over fears his death would be covered up. The -year-old, from Bristol, had complained about being in extreme pain and a growing mass in his stomach, which doctors initially said was gallstones or faeces . From November  to March ,  he lost about six stone and went from a bulky bodybuilder to a shell of a man, Bristol Live reports. Eventually his pain got so bad he could no longer hold a pen so he hid his journals in prison furniture and personal belongings predicting his eventual death. His family only found them after he died when other cell mates told them about the journals - which can be seen below.   He died in Southmead Hospital in March , days after he was diagnosed with terminal cancer. But the health care partnership used by the prison said considerable efforts were made by many healthcare professionals involved in treating Adrian. The journals started off with him writing around an entry a day about how much he missed his children and his plans to get back to them. But it soon started becoming more frantic as he realised he was not going to get the treatment he needed, and it detailed his medication, food, and every aspect of prison le. He writes that he started to “p*** blood”, doubling over in pain, being unable to eat or drink and having to sleep upright in his chair. Adrian initially lost a stone in just  days, and things got worse.  Drawing up a bucket list of things he wanted to do with his six-year-old son, he had hopes things would get better. They didn’t – and by February , he was writing his last letters to his children. Nine months after he died, his daughter Nikita was found dead at home. After Adrian’s death, the journals were handed over to police and the family only received them back in September this year. Avon and Somerset police said they had taken the journals for investigation into potentially involuntary manslaughter from gross negligence. It was unfounded and no further police action was taken. A spokesman for the Ministry of Justice said: “Mr Watts’ claim that his cell was not fit for purpose was fully investigated and found to be unfounded. It was consequently not raised as an issue at the inquest or by the PPO in their report.   “The prison has improved the procedure in place to manage the dietary needs of prisoners with medical needs, in partnership with the healthcare provider.” Health care at Bristol Prison is provided by a partnership made up of several organisations under the name InspireBetterHealth. A spokesperson for the Inspire Better Health partnership, said: On  November , Mr Watts complained of abdominal pain and was referred to a prison GP for this. “He was seen by prison GPs five times in December  and supported by prison nurses as well. Following a referral for suspected cancer from a prison GP on  January , he was assessed by Southmead hospital on  January . “Further tests were carried out by the hospital but sadly Mr Watts’ condition deteriorated and he died on  March . “We appreciate that  was an extremely dficult year for the family of Adrian Watts. His family were understandably concerned by the comments he made in the journals he kept at the time.   “These journals were considered at the official inquest into Mr Watts’ death, which took place on  August . “At the inquest, the family raised concerns about whether there was a delay in diagnosing the cancer . The inquest found that the cancer Mr Watts suffered was extremely dficult to diagnose, and that sadly, diagnosing earlier - between November and January - could not have prevented his death. “At the inquest, there was also a discussion about the dficulties in managing pain. The prison GP explained that this was made more dficult because Mr Watts had been a heroin user and was taking Buprenorphine as a replacement to help reduce the effects of withdrawal. “Considerable efforts were made by many healthcare professionals involved in treating Mr Watts. We appreciate that none of this will bring Mr Watts back and we were very sorry to hear of his death. Adrians diary entries: Note: The four journals consist of tens of thousands of words, with several diary entries nearly every day. Below are excerpts.  Adrian Watts, journal one Adrian has just started writing after he realised he was not getting the treatment he asked for. December  Just been to doc’s about pain and stomach camps, yet all the doc wanted to say was I was to be detoxed of medication. I have no help. No one has approached me about why I am on medication. December  Nurse muddled me up with another inmate and questionedI had been caught ‘palming’… She confused me with someone . I made it clear I do not ‘palm’ medication, thank you!  December  I am feeling scared at what is happening as it’s progressing and getting worse. December  Woke up at .am with massive stomach cramps. For the first hour I was crying with pain until I managed to pass wind a lot which eased my pain a little. I went for medication and spoke to nurse and requested someone to at least feel my stomach but the nurse refused and said he would ask the doctor to see me to do what I asked. The lump on my right side seems massive. December , .pm Really bad chest pains and extreme burps. I need help now. HELP PLEASE. December , .pm Terrible pain. Drank milk to try and loosen up any blocks,any. I can feel the golf-ball size lump between lower rib and pelvis, which hurts some what.  Very concerned it could be a tumour inside. December  He documents he has lost some .kg . Help, I am now depressed. Doctor thinks it is gallstones and I really hope that’s all it is. He suffers “massive cramps”, and says he can’t stop sweating. December  Been hurting all night, but when I did try to lay down, the pain was so bad I have had to sit back upright. Adrian Watts, journal two Adrian is getting desperate for help. He talks about taking his own le. December  I am meant to be studying but can’t concentrate due to pain I am in.   I have again written a ‘listening to you’ form but doubt I will get a reply like the last time. Dozed off but woke up in terrible pain. I prayed for help, I hope God can hear me. December  Asked nurse about the pain. He said no notes were on the system. He did not know anything about ultra sound or where it would be carried out. Stomach cramps are constant but at the moment are really intense. I can’t go to toilet, so much pain. December , PM I feel completely helpless. After drinking water, causes more pain. So along with the swelling in my stomach, I feel as though I’m going to pop, yet I’ve not eaten a meal for two days. HELP. December  He demands to see the doctor and is told his weight is good, and blood test “fine. He is prescribed peppermint oil, and is told he will get a scan “as soon as possible”.   December , Christmas Eve “I can’t stop crying. I am at such a low andI didn’t have the medication I receive each day, I can’t imagine the suffering I would endure.” His wish for Christmas is to be “pain free for a while”. December , Christmas Day Was up all night sat up, really tired. Don’t want to eat anything for fear of the pain. December  Spent almost all night rocking on my bed. It feels asa hot poker is being pushed into my stomach. I am really worried what is wrong. God help me, fingers crossed I can see a doctor today. December  Things look up when he sees GP for fourth time, albeit a dferent doctor. Upon examination, the doctor said it could be Irritable Bowel Syndrome, but assures Adrian “it is not stomach cancer” because blood test results have ed.   “I left feeling much better and I am to try another medication for IBS.” December  I have a massive swollen stomach and both sides of my ribs are killing me. Just told the nurse. He told me not to let my head think about it too much. Is he having a laugh  January , noon Pain has relented after medication, thank God. I was in so much pain this morning, had some dinner, breaded fish and rice. January  Draws out a flow chart, detailing how he believes it to be cancer and contemplating self harming so the prison service will “take it seriously” enough to send him to hospital. He is feeling “ ” anxious and despair and writes his heart rate is increasing and he is sweaty. Frustrated at the lack of help, he holds his breath to control his pain and contemplates using Spice, but is worried about the aggression. “This was what the head of healthcare gave me after a long conversation to tell me I was imagining the pain.” “I am going to die in prison because the healthcare didn’t listen. I am in agony. January , am I am using this moment to write as a way to focus. I ate earlier, so that must be why I am in so much pain. No more food. January AM meds as normal. Chaplin came to my cell this morning, Naiidine is worried, I am so sorry for my children. We prayed together and I told the chaplin this feels like my punishment. January The pain I am being left in is so bad, now I have just received a letter saying from December , the day I began recording my treatment, the legal aid system no longer covers medical negligence.Adrian Watts, journal three He has a bucket list of things he wants to do with his son when he gets out. Bucket listTake Adrian to Disneyland Paris full -star treatment. Buy a house Live to get out Diet:Baked beans – no Sausages – no Sugars – no Chicken – no Energy drinks – No Eggs – ok Breaded fish – okWeight:   - .kg   - . kg  days lost -kg January , .am Unable to sleep as the pain in stomach is terrible. Used the suppository but had to go to toilet straight after and it came out. January  Up all night, so tired, tried to sleep but too painful to lay down. Spoke to nurse about fact I am not eating at all, feel so weak. Did try to eat an orange, but again the backache was instant. Hopefully I’m out to hospital early this week.  January  .kg PM meds. Had my observations done as I have been in so much pain today. A lump the size of a tennis ball is the centre of it and under my ribs as well. January , .am I am tempted to call for help but being totally honest, I know they will do nothing as my obs will show normal. January , .am Alice the nice nurse came and took my obs. My gall bladder is really sore and I keep getting sharp pains in my stomach. January , PM I used to think it was irrational to think that making a complaint in prison could so easily be dismissed or covered up but my evidence was taken by a doctor in front of Alice. January  I used to think it was irrational to think that making a complaint in prison could so easily be dismissed or covered up but my evidence. I never done anything so bad I have to go through this for months.  FIX UP ADE - be strong. It’s bad, but you’re strong and you have to get through. Read the bible like you have been and believe this is your punishment. January  I had tied myself to my bed to prevent me falling off of chair again as I did last night. I feel pain in my chest and told the healthcare nurse but it’s not helping. February , am . kg My whole right side is killing me and the pain is massive. It feels swollen up. I am scared. No one knows why I’m being left to suffer, I can’t think straight. February , .pm Two officers just came to my cell and told me I have been put on a suicide actbecause I’m upset the doctor has stopped my only pain relief. He talks about taking his le. Adrian Watts, journal four Adrian is told he has cancer, and its spread. He is devastated and finishes it mid-sentence.  Bucket list Stay at Ashculme House in DevonFebruary , .pm Due to the fact the doctor has decided to stop the suppository without telling me, I’ve been left in massive pain. The slight relief they could give me has left me now in agony again. February , .am AM meds as normal. Got called to see the GP and she told me my scan results show serious concerns. My lymph glandsare all up in my groin area, bowel, chest, so I HAVE CANCER. Absolutely confused as the doctor had such little information about me. Maybe someone will come and speak about my options etc, my emotions are all over the place. February , .pm Massive pain in stomach. Can’t think straight, my whole body is hurting. Chaplin came to see me and went straight to the kitchen when I told him I still had not received any food. The pain is off the charts. I need to see ‘mental health’ [teams] really but they are non-existent. February , AM .kg Unable to even write this journal at the moment. February After being left without any pain relief all night last night, officers came to my cell at .am before I had a chance to wash and told me I was to go out into public and attend a hospital appointment. I could not walk so I was taken in a wheelchair. February , am Having to sleep sitting upright is so hard. I have a chair in front of me to rest my head on to stop falling forward, but I have found I am resting on my jaw and it’s locking up, plus my arms go dead all the time. February , .am Meds brought to cell as I am unable to move. Spoke to nurse about constant pain getting worse and also the fact my urine is almost brown in colour. March , .amHad to call for morphine all night and I just had a dose. I wee but I really need to keep drinking due to concentrated urinenot. Doctor ... title: kray twins secret friendship mum
story: NewsKray twins secret friendship with mum of Moors murder victim revealedRonnie and Reggie Kray formed a close bond with Ann Downer, whose daughter Lesley Ann, , was abducted, raped, tortured and killed by Ian Brady and Myra HindleyShareCommentsByAntonia Paget:,  DEC NewsAnn Wests son believes she struck up a relationship with the Krays to learn about her daughters killers time in prison "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The mum of a Moors murders victim was befriended by the jailed Kray twins, two of Britain’s most violent gangsters.Killers Ronnie and Reggie Kray formed a strange secret bond with Ann Downey, the mum of tragic -year-old victim Lesley Ann. The notorious twins, who had shared a jail wing with Moors murderer Ian Brady, became obsessed with the sickening murder of the young girl. They sent numerous letters to Ann which her son discovered after her death. Terry West also found letters from sadistic Brady and fellow Moors shymurderer Myra Hindley. They cruelly taunted her over Lesley Ann’s rape, torture and murder on Boxing Day in . The Krays’ letters were dferent in tone.   Terry, , said: “They are not the kind of letters you would expect from criminals like the Krays. “Everyone knows how vicious the Krays could be. Maybe mum was trying to find out more about Brady in prison. I’d no idea until after mum died they had been shywriting to one another.”Terry was researching his memoir If Only when he found the letters in a bulging suitcase in his late mum’s bedroom. Ann once said the twins had written to her but was very protective of Terry and his siblings and did not elaborate. He said: “Only now do I really know the extent of the relationship.   “She only ever wanted to know more about what happened to her daughter. If they brought her comfort then I can understand why she wrote to them.” He is unsure who had contacted who first: “Maybe she was trying to get information about Brady in prison, I honestly can’t tell. It’s funny to think of my little mum talking to these two ruffians.” Terry hopes the bizarre relationship brought solace to Ann who never recovered from the trauma of losing Lesley Ann, buried naked in a shallow grave on Lancashire’s bleak Saddleworth Moor. She was one of five children aged shybetween ten and  murdered by the evil pairs.Ann West died in  aged  after a long battle with liver cancer but her lelong campaign to keep the monsters behind bars was successful. Both died in hospital as prisoners - Hindley in  aged  and -year-old Brady last year.   The Krays’ letters are from the s. They had known Brady, who was locked up on the same wing as them in HMP Durham in the late s and early s. In  the Krays’ violent reign of protection rackets, armed robberies, arson came to an end when they were jailed for le for murder. In , Ronnie, , died after a heart attack in Broadmoor. Reggie passed five years later of bladder cancer aged . Their letters to Ann, written in shynear-illegible scrawl, show an unusual side to the violent criminals. Terry said: “When I looked at the letters I could barely read them. They look like they’ve been written by a child.”A letter from Reggie, on personalised headed paper from HMP Maidstone, says: “Thank you for your letter and I pray that you have peace of mind [and] soul.”The letters reveal the twins tried to meet Ann and her husband Andy but Terry insisted this never took place. Ronnie wrote in one letter dated August : “I am very sorry but I won’t be able to see you in September as we arranged as I have had all my visits cut down to seven a month, but I will keep in touch from time to time. God bless.”  Terry, of Withington, Gtr Manchester, said: “It’s nice to see a dferent side to the infamous Kray twins with their polite tone.” Brady was in HMP Durham from  until , where the Krays were also held from .He would later boast at a mental health tribunal that he used to cook steaks with the twins. But Terry believes this was pure shyfantasy. He said: “I think that was shyanother one of his lies. Brady wanted to change the perception of himself from a paedophile serial killer to some sort of Ned Kelly gangster. He wanted to play with the big boys.” Terry is sure the Krays would have turned on Brady because of his heinous crimes.He said: “If they had got shyanywhere near him you can only shyimagine what they would have done to him. I think they would have shyseriously hurt him. “I know they were ruffians and gangsters and all of that but they didn’t hurt children.” Brady and Hindley were convicted of luring children and teenagers to their deaths from July  and October . Brady was jailed in  for murdering John Kilbride, , Lesley Ann, and Edward Evans, , and later admitted to killing Pauline Reade, , and Keith Bennett. The -year-old’s body is believed to be on the moor but has never been found, despite pleas for Brady to reveal his final resting place by Keith’s mother Winnie Johnson, who died in . Lesley Ann’s remains were found in  and laid to rest near her home. It was later moved to a secret location after her grave was heartlessly desecrated. For three years, on what would have been Lesley’s birthday, the graffiti “Myra Hindley” was scrawled in black paint across the headstone. Now Lesley lies in a grave alongside her mother Ann, and Terry makes a weekly pilgrimage to their final resting place to lay flowers.He admits he still feels guilty over her disappearance as he was bed-ridden with flu and had not gone with his younger sister to the fair where she was abducted. He said: “I see the -something man in the mirror and the mental scars of pain look back at me.” When Terry visits their grave on Boxing Day he will lay a wreath to honour their memory. He said: “The pain of her death will never get easier, and I think about it every day. “But I am happy my mum and sister are at peace together. “I imagine them both as angels sitting in heaven – just like the angel on top of the Christmas tree.”

story: NewsMum goes BLIND after developing brain infection on dream Caribbean holidayCathrine Ndlovu, , was struck down with rhombencephalitis, a le-threatening brain infection, while on a family trip to the Dominican RepublicShareCommentsByNeil Murphy:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsMum-of-one Cathrine Ndlovu developed a rare brain infection"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum was struck down with a serious brain infection while on a dream Caribbean holiday, leaving her unable to walk, talk or see. Cathrine Ndlovu, , flew out to the Dominican Republic with her elderly mother Musa, aunt Tendai and eight-year-old son Brodie in August. She began suffering from earaches and headaches on her second day in the country and decided to seek medical help. But she was misdiagnosed by doctors and her condition was left untreated for two weeks before being flown out of the country without proper assistance.  She had her wisdom teeth removed in a local hospital after being told that was the cause of her problem. But the next day the pain became much worse and she started to lose her eyesight. Cathrine ed to the hospital and was admitted for three days where medics said she had suffered a stroke and diagnosed her with Multiple Sclerosis. It was only after herto the UK that she was told she was suffering from rhombencephalitis, a le-threatening brain stem infection.  Catherine, who works as a Border Force officer, spent months in intensive care at Manchester Royal Infirmary. She has learned to walk and talk again after suffering from brain damage due to the condition. Because she did not have critical care insurance Catherine was forced to fork out pound, for the medical bills during her stay in hospital in the Dominican Republic.  Friends and family have launched a GoFundMe appeal for Catherine who has been unable to s to her job since August . Her friend Kelly Francis explained Catherines ordeal on the GoFundMe appeal. She write: She lost control of her right arm and had no sight in her right eye, but was still discharged from hospital three days later and told she would be fit to fly home on her booked flight eight days later.   On the day Cathrine ed home, she had no eye sight, had not drunk or eaten for one week, was unable to swallow and could not walk, explained Kelly. However, being the true fighter she is, Cathrine was determined to get home with her eight-year-old son and by a miracle survived the flight.  Catherine has thanked those who have contributed to her fund, which so far has raised pound,. Work has been amazing colleagues and friends have visited and even come up with the GoFundMe fundraising idea for me, said Cathrine. Ive had so much support its been wonderful, but I really want to get to Salford Neuro Ward now and take the next steps on the rehabilitation journey. Im determined to be home by Christmas and reunited with my son. Thank you so much for all you help its very much appreciated.

title: suicidal mum jump car park
story: NewsSuicidal mum about to jump off car park saved by stranger who refused to let goCharley Wills, , from Wakefield, was sectioned after the incident but has since begun her recovery and is on the mendShareCommentsBySusie Beever:,  DEC NewsA stranger saved Charleys le "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young mum has revealed how a stranger saved her le by clinging to her waist and refusing to let go as she was about to jump off a multi-storey car park. Charley Wills was at her lowest ebb after leaving an abusive relationship and spiralled into a dark place which left her crippled with depression. In September, the beauty therapist found herself driving to a multi-storey car park, where she sat on the edge in a bid to end her le. However the -year-old was stopped by a Samaritan who she has now been reconnected with, reports Examiner Live. Charley, who has a one-year-old son named Hugo, said: I just couldnt handle all things that were happening to me. I had lost my home and a lot of people in my le. I felt like nobody understood and I just needed a cuddle. Id got really ill and Hugo was going back to his dads for a few days. That was the day everything went crashing down. I drove to the top of the multi-storey car park - there were so many thoughts going through my head.  In my head I was there for only five minutes but in reality it was probably about an hour. This lady came over and held my waist. She said, lets just go and get a cup of coffee, things are going to be okay. Every time I inched closer to the edge she would just hold me. If it werent for her and the police lady who turned up, my little boy would have no one to tuck him into bed at night. Charley, who is originally from Honley but now lives with her sister Casey in Wakefield, was sectioned after the incident, but has since begun her recovery and is on the mend. She added: I know my worth now. The day I was sectioned, I would have still got back with my ex. Then I got a message from him saying I should have jumped. To say that to your childs mother is disgusting. In a bid to find the stranger who helped her, Charley put a post on Facebook in the hope it would reach her. Facebook delivered, after the post was shared hundreds of times and it was spotted by someone who knew the lady and tagged her in it.  I sent her a message on Facebook just to say thank you along with a picture of my son, said Charley. She replied saying that just knowing I was okay was enough in the way of thanks. I honestly cant thank all these people enough. If it werent for her, the police officer, and my sister Casey, Hugo would be without a mum to put him to bed and to watch TV with. There are so many people in this situation who are in abusive or manipulative relationships and need to get out. I realise now that Im worth  times more than he made me feel. The Samaritans is available  you need to talk. You can contact them for free by calling  , email jo@samaritans.org or head to the website to find your nearest branch. You matter.

title: terrified mum thought dying after
story: NewsTerried mum thought she was dying after % of her hair fell out in two weeksEXCLUSIVE Mum-of-three Jo Tucker has shared photos of some of her fabulous wigs after suddenly losing the hair on her head and bodyShareCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter:,  DEC NewsJo Tucker has alopecia universalis, complete loss of hair on the scalp and body "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who thought she was dying when she suddenly lost her hair has revealed how her young daughters deal with her condition. Jo Tucker, , says  per cent of her hair was gone in two weeks and the rest followed, which happened out of nowhere and for no apparent reason. The mum-of-three, from Bath, said she found the lack of control hideous and traumatic as she not only lost the hair on her head, but also on her body. Having alopecia initially made her feel ugly and lost and with no explanation why, she says she even thought she was dying. But Jo embraced her condition, pulling off vibrant, fabulous wigs and courageously posting pictures online of her bald head to raise awareness of alopecia. She says she was determined to speak openly about living with her condition - including to her little girls. Matilda, nine, Elsie, six, and Ivy, one, have taken their mums alopecia in their stride, and speak honestly about it, asking questions that come to their minds. Jo says they have asked why it had happened, why mummy has no eyelashes, and when her hair will come back.  Speaking to Mirror online Jo said: I talk to them so they know they can talk to me about anything. They ask why it happened. My eldest daughter asks to dress up in my wigs. Matilda will ask would you like to borrow my black hat  Elsie asks the most questions. She asks why dont you have any eyelashes and when will your hair grow back  I give them the answer that it might grow back or it might not, and they move on. I have tried to take an approach where I explain to them that mummy is fine but now she gets the opportunity to wear dferent hair that she likes. They say mummy, why dont you wear this one and oh mummy you are quite lucky because you get to wear this hair. They also say things like mum, one day you can have short hair and the next day long. Matilda has got the best understanding of it -she spots anybody without hair she says oh she hasnt got hair like you.  Jo, who works as a buyer, said her hair loss happened between December  to January this year. She said she noticed a patch missing on the underneath of her hair. But this had happened during her second pregnancy and everything had grown back after she gave birth, so she wasnt worried. After having her third daughter, she says she also had a little patch appear and disappear again. But this time it was dferent.  In December, the shedding ramped up and I was noticing it in my hands, and it escalated, Jo, who used to have a pixie hairstyle, recalled. I went to the doctor and had blood tests but by that point  percent of it had gone - in about two weeks over the Christmas period. It was so rapid, it was coming out in clumps in the shower. I could feel it falling, it was really weird. I could touch the ends of my hair and a clump would come out in my hands, it was really traumatic. When I went back to work after Christmas I needed a wig I had lost that much.  Jo was diagnosed with alopecia areata around January time, a general term for hair loss that can occur at any age. But by February this had developed into alopecia universalis, complete loss of hair on the scalp and body. Her arm hair was the last to go in March. Jo said she had blood tests which showed that technically nothing was wrong with her. She says she wasnt going through a particularly stressful period when she lost her hair, adding it really did seem to come from nowhere.  At first, Jo struggled to deal with what was happening. She said: When it first started happening it was really traumatic. I felt really disgusting and ugly. You just dont feel normal. The lack of control is hideous. I couldnt put a stop to it. I felt really lost. For a really long time it was awful. You just dont know whats going on. I genuinely thought I was dying. Going back to work, I think I just cried solidly for a week. Then I went for afitting, which was amazing. It brought me back a tiny bit of confidence.  She added: I was worried about what my husband would think of me, would he still find me attractive . Itseems so signicant but psychologically and mentally it goes way deeper than how you look. Jo said her husband Joe has taken her condition into his stride and he doesnt seem to notice it anymore. She said that everything just started falling, joking Im the smoothest person I know. Jo said she has even lost her eyebrows, eyelashes, and nostril hair, and says in the end she clipped off the last whispy bits on her head. I even miss the little bit of moustache I used to have, its really strange, she added.  But Jo keeps amazingly positive for her girls and embraces changing her style daily. The mum says she doesnt want Matilda, Elsie, and Ivy to think shes unwell as technically theres nothing wrong with me. She explained: I tell them some people just dont have any hair and its fine. Children adapt really well. They embrace the hair thing with me. I have got a pink wig they love. I was conscious and didnt want their friends to talk about me, I didnt want it to be a negative thing. I have been blatant about it because I change the colours of the wigs. My eldest daughter asks to dress up in them. We always try and talk to the girls and say there are lots of dferent people in the world, who might have dferent ailments.  She added: I had been worried about other people saying things to them - and worried about them worrying about me . Its just everyday le for themnow. I worry it could be hereditary, I worry for their sakes. Jo, who thinks it is unlikely her hair will grow back, says she has found the community of people on Instagram with alopecia supportive. She said: Its like being a member of a club no one wants membership for in the first place.Shes also open with friends about her condition. I take the lead in being open on the subject, so friends are open to talking about it, she said. I try to make people feel comfortable with it.  Jos highs and lows of daily le with alopecia Highs - Embracing the wig wearing - I have cut my getting ready time down as I can whizz my wig on and Im done - Ive got salon looking hair every day - The bond you make with someone  who has got alopecia - its like youre in a sisterhood - Inspiring other people - Ive had messages saying my daughter is suffering and you have helped.  Lows - It feels and looks so strange when I wake up - Its a pain to have to draw in my eyebrows every day - Wearing glasses is a pain with a wig as you have to tuck the arms into the hair- Having a cold and my nose running uncontrollably - which is embarrassing- Girls holidays are challenging - youre either sweating in a wig or embracing the baldness - Exercise classes - you just want to blend in but you stick out.

story: NewsArchaeologists discover ancient ,-year-old tomb decorated with hieroglyphs in EgyptThe ancient tomb is one of many discoveries made by archaeologists on Egyptian soil this year - and more are expectedShareCommentsByJasmine Rapson:,  DEC Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video egypt-unveils--year-old-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA well-preserved ancient tomb has been discovered south of the Egyptian capital of Cairo - and more exciting finds are expected in the coming months. The tomb is decorated with hieroglyphs and statues and archaeologists are preparing to make more discoveries as they excavate the site. It was found buried in a ridge untouched and unlooted at the ancient necropolis of Saqqara, according to Mostafa Waziri, secretary-general of the Supreme Council of Antiquities. He described the latest find as one of a kind in the last decades.The tomb dates from the rule of Neferirkare Kakai, the third king of the Fth Dynasty of the Old Kingdom.  Archaeologists removed a last layer of debris from the tomb on Thursday and found five shafts inside. One of the shafts was unsealed with nothing inside, however the other four were sealed and teams are expecting to make discoveries when they start uncovering the shafts on Sunday. Waziri is particularly hopeful about one of the shafts, which he believes could lead to a coffin.I can imagine that all of the objects can be found in this area. This shaft should lead to a coffin or a sarcophagus of the owner of the tomb. The tomb is  metreslong, three metreswide and just under three metres high.  Waziri said the tomb is unique because of the statues and its near perfect condition.He said: The colour is almost intact even though the tomb is almost , years old.The tomb lies in a buried ridge that has only partially been uncovered and more discoveries are expected to be made there when archaeologists start more excavation work in January.The Fth Dynasty ruled Egypt from about , BC to , BC, not long after the great pyramid of Giza was built.Saqqara served as the necropolis for Memphis, the capital of ancient Egypt for more than two millennia.Ancient Egyptians mummied humans to preserve their bodies for the afterle, while animal mummies were used as religious offerings. Egypt has revealed over a dozen ancient discoveries this year.The country hopes the finds will brighten its image abroad and revive interest among travelers who once flocked to its iconic pharaonic temples and pyramids but who fled after the  political uprising.

title: hundreds join yellow vest demo
story: NewsHundreds join yellow vest demo in Dublin in solidarity with French protestsThe "yellow vest" movement began in France in mid-November in protest against fuel tax increasesShareCommentsByMichael McHugh:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsCampaigners outside Custom House before marching to Leinster House "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHundreds of people in Dublin have taken to the streets in solidarity with the French yellow vest demonstrations. Protesters donned yellow vests and some had hard hats, while others tied scarves over their faces. Those who gathered outside the Custom House overlooking the River Lfey before marching to parliament at Leinster House included pro-Palestinian organisations and socialist republicans. Others involved in the gathering said they were concerned about the use of fluoride in the public water supply. While anti-Government chanting could be heard.  The yellow vest movement in France, which takes its name from the fluorescent safety vests French motorists must carry in their vehicles, emerged in mid-November as a protest against fuel tax increases. It soon expanded into an expression of rage about the high cost of living in France and President Emmanuel Macrons policies. It comes as tear gas has been fired on the streets of Paris during a fth week of nationwide protests against the French government. Ignoring calls not to demonstrate following a gun attack in Strasbourg earlier this week, thousands of yellow vest activists were out in a huge show of strength.  In Paris, police were out in force to contain possible outbursts of violence. Tear gas was fired at small groups of protesters in brief clashes with riot police near the Champs-Elysees. Close by, a handful of topless activists from the feminist protest group Femen faced security forces a few meters away from the Elysee Palace, the presidents residence. The yellow vest movement started in mid-November with protests at junctions and roundabouts against fuel tax increases, but quickly became a wider mobilisation against Macrons economic policies.  Successive weekends of protests in Paris have lead to vandalism and violent clashes with security forces. But several major stores, such as the Galeries Lafayette, were open to welcome Christmas shoppers. Numbers were down compared to Saturday last week, a police source said. Loic Bollay, , marching on the Champs-Elysees in a yellow vest, said the protests were more subdued than in previous weeks but the movement would go on until the demonstrators grievances were addressed. Since the Strasbourg attack, it is calmer, but I think next Saturday and the following Saturdays... it will come back. The Interior Minister said around , police were active on Saturday with a reinforced presence in the cities of Toulouse, Bordeaux and Saint-Etienne.  A police source told Reuters some , protesters had been counted in France, excluding Paris, by am, compared to , at the same time on December . In Paris, where groups of hundreds of protesters marched in splintered groups in several neighbourhoods,  had been arrested by around midday, according to a Paris police official. On Friday, President Macron called for ato calm in France after nearly a month of protests by the so-called yellow vest movement against his governments policies. The demonstrations have hit growth and caused widespread disruption.  France needs calm, order and ato normal, Macron said, after a meeting of European Union leaders in Brussels. In a televised address to the nation on Monday, Macron announced wage rises for the poorest workers and tax cuts for pensioners in further concessions meant to end the movement but many said they would maintain pressure. The government, as well as several unions and opposition politicians called on protesters to stay off the streets on Saturday, after four people were killed in a gun attack at a Christmas market in the historic city of Strasbourg.

I am grateful for opportunities to speak with Nat, Miss Cambodia, and H’Hen, Miss Vietnam, directly about this experience. These are the moments that matter most to me.
